mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: Annie is light on its feet, frothy, and always insistently, at times provocatively kind, determined to melt grumpy hearts like marshmallows.
Annie is not a great movie musical — but it’s a fun time at the movies.

In a holiday season when family movie entertainment is in short supply, Annie is bubbly enough to suit the purpose while irritating purists wonder where their orphan went. At times it's actually a lot of fun, and leapin' lizards the sun really does come out tomorrow. Right after the helicopter chase.
It seems sadly apt that the Daddy Warbucks figure played by Jamie Foxx in the new Annie is a cellphone mogul. Because Foxx is pretty much phoning in his performance.
Even with all this sparkle, the film staggers through its third act. By then, the script has rubbed the rough edges off the villains and made whatever point it was going to make several times over.

Annie has never been the most sophisticated of children's stories. The latest version is formulaic and predictable, but it has its charms, not the least of which is Wallis' easy smile and sassy screen presence.
When Annie isn’t functioning as a showcase for Wallis’ tiny preternatural charm, it’s tonally varied to the point of discombobulation.
Considering this musical has its roots in Depression-era American, Gluck’s contemporary take on the material is eerily lacking in observations about the rich/poor divide in this country.

Quvenzhané Wallis is adorably plucky as the lead in Annie. She and Jamie Foxx as the newfangled Daddy Warbucks character have an appealing chemistry and their songs together are the best moments in the movie. But the rest of Annie is banal, shallow and markedly cynical.
The movie feels like a vanity production, although it's difficult to determine whose ego is being stroked by this expensive adaptation.

The unforced cleverness of the opening scenes gives way to lazy plotting, awkwardly staged musical numbers, and car chases. By the end, the movie resembles just another formulaic, family-friendly piece of product, one the kids will enjoy and you’ll endure as it goes in the DVD player for the 40th time.

Musical theater versions often seem dated, so moving the story into the 21st century does make sense (as does the multicultural casting), but in the process Gluck and his all-star cast create a chaotic film that tries too hard and  fails to capture the charm and heart of the musical.

There are some very funny moments in the movie, even for grown-ups, including a video of Will that goes viral. The absurd machinations of Will’s smarmy political adviser are also good for a laugh. But ultimately, Annie is so fixated on being current that it will never be more than a passing fancy.
The problem is that hardly anyone in the cast can sing or dance on a level that’s more than passable (Foxx is a fine exception). And that’s a problem when the movie is a musical.
Broadway purists determined to hate Annie need not fear, because there’s plenty worth complaining about.

Little girls will love it. I used to be a little girl once, too. I didn’t care much for the Top 40 glossy coat slathered over every song, but this heart will never harden to a spunky kid who’s certain the sun’ll come out tomorrow.
No amount of self-referential jokes can make up for a lack of heart and spirit. Thankfully, Annie lacks neither.

Even the show-stopper "Tomorrow" comes off as half-hearted and obligatory. The choreography looks like it was improvised by the young actors who play Wallis' fellow foster kids — all listless jumping and arm-folding, no inventiveness or energy.
A mushy mix of sentiment and some off-key singing lets the air out of this beloved musical's limo tires.

As far as holiday films go this is perfect for lightening the holiday hangover but ultimately it's equal parts onerous and energetic, overreaching in its attempt not buckle under the weight of previous iterations.
For all the talent involved, the overall effect is surprisingly flat. Foxx appears disconnected, Byrne is wasted and a painfully hammy Diaz seems to be in another movie altogether.
It presumes that children care a great deal about cellphone towers, political campaigns, and Twitter. Still, Quvenzhané Wallis, as Annie, is raw, charismatic, alive, and unpredictable.
Perhaps the most hypercurrent thing about Gluck’s film is how it espouses the value of family while actually celebrating products as the only true form of modern connection.
Unfortunately, the longer this Annie goes on, the more steam it loses.

The overall vibe of this folly is curdled and utterly blase; it's a 118-minute foregone conclusion, finesse-free and perilously low on the simple performance pleasures we look for in any musical, of any period.

Wallis, who is an appealing young performer, simply doesn't have the chops for what has traditionally been one of the more demanding leads in a musical for a young performer, and Gluck, along with co-writer Aline Brosh McKenna, has built a film around Wallis that is constantly undercutting the songs, the choreography, and the entire idea of musicals.

The new Annie musical starring Jamie Foxx and Quvenzhané Wallis is pretty bad, but let’s be honest: Despite some decent show tunes, the show was pretty bad to begin with, so it’s not worth getting all righteous about the dumb changes.
Director Will Gluck's glam, grim re-imagining of the Depression-era musical about the hard-hearted rich man and the little girl who melts him, is truly depressing.

The cast would have been better served by a middle school production overseen by a creatively frustrated, inappropriately ambitious drama teacher than by this hacky, borderline-incompetent production, which was directed by Will Gluck from a screenplay by Aline Brosh McKenna.
The film replaces choreography with metronomic editing, while one-note overstatement drowns out character development.
Of the movie’s dozen musical numbers, only three are relatively unmangled versions of their predecessors.
Fans of previous incarnations are advised to check their nostalgia at the door, while the uninitiated may simply check their brains.
Aside from an unintentional homage to "Zoolander" that is so tone-deaf it'll make you guffaw, Annie goes out of its way to make viewing it a hard-knock life...for us.

Putting aside the grating performances, the clumsy direction, the visual ugliness and the haphazard development of story, character and relationships, the movie is hobbled by its intrinsic unsuitability for contemporary retelling.
The worst Hollywood musical so far this century, it’s another misstep for Sony Pictures, which also sponsored the abortive ‘‘The Interview.’’
2014: Annie's America makes director John Huston's elephantine, synthetically charismatic 1982 adaptation look like a Minnelliesque model of focus and concision.

Where to begin in describing the awfulness of Annie? Why not with Sandy, Annie’s dog, whose name now connects with the superstorm in this hapless contemporary update of a musical that begged to be left in its 1930s period. Have you ever seen a dog suffer from incompetent direction? This one does, but no more or less so than the human members of the cast, none of whom have any emotional connection with one another, let alone with a standoffish pooch.

When a stage musical as beloved as Annie hits the big screen and falls ignominiously on its fat one, you might ask: WTF? For starters, updating the Depression-era tale to NYC 2014 is a really dumb idea. The strain of the shoehorning is evident in every scene.

mc_user_reviews.text: basically this movie has ruined my childhood the songs are nothing like the originals Annie has better clothing than me and she is supposed to be an orphan and then she has Instagram and twitter and sandy is a well groomed dog that should actually be a scruffy shaggy dog I get yous are trying to make it different but the original is the best

Annie reeks of one of those vanity projects where a bunch of rich and famous people who are good at certain things thought they could translate their knowledge of those things into a good movie. In this case, two of the film’s rich and famous producers – Jay-Z and Will Smith – certainly know a thing or two about music.  But knowing music and the music business, even in the context of also knowing movies and the movie business (in Smith’s case), does not make someone an expert on movie musicals.  This film is hard knock proof of that.

Let me start with the good points: Jamie Fox did a nice job of playing Stacks, the new Warbucks. That almost sickeningly cute Wallis kid was just that. Hard Knock Life was a well done musical number. There were a few funny cute moments that made me smile.

Are you kidding me, critics? This is a very pleasant movie for the ages. I can't believe how low the rating is. I mean, it's impossible not to be charmed by "Annie". Well, there are some cheesy parts, of course. But, the laughs covered it because it keeps on coming and it's done with finesse.

Prior to seeing this movie, I was very skeptical about this new 'remake' of the classic Annie. I thought that they had changed too much (the name of Oliver Warbucks changed to William Stacks, etc), which originally made led me to the conclusion that I would not see the movie. I ended up going anyways with a friend, and I must say- I take back all former remarks about this new Annie movie, as it was phenomenal. I was shocked to see such a low score here on MetaCritic, so here I am to contribute my positive review of this amazing film.

Annie is a god awful film that is shockingly worst when nobody is singing. If the purpose was to feel empathy for Annie and create a emotional connection between the characters, than its nearly a failure. Some of the songs are the worst I've ever heard from a musical and Cameron Diaz gives one of the worst performances of the year.

it was pretty good but the original will always be better.  My family did foster care and when she went back to live with her mother that what she was doing in the backseat of the car, that made me cry.
Horrible. The original is so much better than the newer version. The original version for the musical was amazing. But the newer version plain sucks. Don't see the newer version.

I love Quvenzhane Wallis and Jamie Foxx's performance, but somebody forgot to watch the original Annie and see how it's done. Look, I don't wanna be so mean to Sony, but making a reboot to the beloved 1982 Annie feels like you wanted to make tons of money at the box office and should probably get awards. Unfortunately, the movie stinks. Cameron Diaz. Why is that blonde bimbo in this movie, anyway? She did her worse in Sex Tape, now this. In the original, Hannigan is one of the greatest villains of all time where she was a drunken caretaker and punish many orphanage girls like doing chores, scrubbing the bathroom, and allowing her butler, Rooster, to kill Annie. Dude, Carol Burnett was in the original. A true legendary classic. This is what musical movies is all about. But this Hannigan by Diaz, just complete rubbish. If any movie that should be in the worst movies of 2014 is Annie. Don't even bother seeing it this Christmas because once the Razzies coming up, Worst Remake, Prequel, Reboot, or Sequel, Worst Actress (Diaz), Worst Director, and Worst Picture should do the trick.
this was worst movie ever i mean why did the even remake a movie that been Remake so many time

The movie was an audio/visual assault. My wife forced me to take her to watch it. 20 minutes in she was already whispering apologies for the wreck and regret of wasting her movie choice turn on such a poorly directed piece. It seems the cast and director never had a sit down to review and cohesive vision for the remake thoughout the entire filming.
Rehash of a classic musical but it was terrible. My mother and I watched the first, but this one was a mess. Nothing was wrong with a black girl as a lead, but the acting was disgusting.

What's with everyone bullfricking about this movie being "bad"? I mean, yes, the lyrics might be simplistic, and the choreography might be somewhat lacking, and the movie may have a touch of one or two plotholes, but the story's solid and has one of the lightest attitudes I've seen in a long time, even if it's a reboot of a movie I haven't seen. I mean, sure, Big Hero 6 and HTTYD2 may also have their places, but they're animated. It's so much of a happy ride that even if all of you don't find my review helpful at all, it's worth noting that they are at least *trying* to make us happy. Seeing this made me happier than -- slightly unrelated, but -- the modern purple lizard from Toys R Us. Annie is cute, even if she can be hard to look at at times.

We saw this with our 8-year-old daughter. She loved the movie. As the parents, we were expecting the worst as we are both familiar with the original Broadway show and the previous film versions. We were pleasantly surprised. We were not expecting it to be a cookie-cutter of past versions, which was a good thing - if you have such love for the originals, then this version will annoy you. It brings it to the current age in the rewrites of some of the songs and the inclusion of social media as part of the plot lines. We all thought that the actors did a good job with their characters. The directing and production could have been a bit more honed, but let's not forget that this is a movie made for the younger set. It is heaps better than Spy Kids 4.

The Great Annie was born in the Great Depression and she was a white/ginger girl. It was a great film, a true classic. This remake isn't Annie. The true story of Annie here is all wrong, sorry it's not racial to me, it's just not the correct story. I won't see this one. Sorry, the story Annie I saw years ago, that is Annie

My wife and I went to see this and both left a little over 30 minutes in. Believe me, this is quite possibly the worst film of 2014, and I've seen quite a few stinkers. Save your money and sanity - AVOID ANNIE!

I recently saw the movie and it was amazing. It had a great amount of heart and was incredibly witty with a lot of comedy. All you people who gave it a bad review need to check yourselves just because the main characters were African American doesn't mean you should say bad things. I also saw the first  movie and it was way too serious it wasn't funny and they made Daddy Warbucks an unemotional rude man so before you say rude things about the remake watch the first then see remake you sons of ****
The movie was overall a complete mess. It doesnt follow quite of the original musical. Plus, the main character is black and african, as opposed to the white in orgininal.

I never seen the original, but I'll have to admit the film isn't bad. The songs are enjoyable (especially the Hard knock life one). The cast was okay. So I recommend if anyone want to see a movie this week, try Annie.

Seeing all the negative reviews, I still went ahead and watched the movie. It was a fun movie, if you need a break from the Exodus or the Interview playing in theatres. Walis as Annie is very nice, as she is adorable. Jamie Foxx was unnecessary but it's alright. Diaz was Not as good  but Will Gluck really recreated the songs and whatnot very masterfully. I know this is a childish review, but it's actually very good for family audiences. I would recommend this for kids and families.

I was unsure about the movie when I first saw the previews b/c I am a fan of the original Annie. I was invited to take my daughter (age 4) to see it & she has watched the original with me. After seeing the 2014 version I enjoyed it! No it wasn't "exactly" like the original which most remakes aren't, it wasn't suppose to be. I feel people are more focused on who played Annie  (amongst the other characters ) rather than the plot of the movie itself. It was a updated musical. I would watch it again just as much as the original. Watch the movie for what it is & take color out of it!

This movie is painful and pointless interpretation of a classic that needlessly and awkwardly changes race out of pure desperation to get some kind of response from viewers and shield itself from criticism. Having a black Annie makes no sense, and it doesnt justify the films existence at all so the agenda has to be something out of vanity, a crime Will Smith is so guilty of it discredits him as an actor. Cameron Diaz also can't seem to stop sucking for one second to act.
For those people saying that  "the movie was bad" DON'T FORGET THAT THIS IS A MUSICAL MOVIE FOR KIDS!!! MY FAMILY AND I LOVED IT!! VERY TOUCHING, GREAT ACTORS, GREAT MUSIC!!

I grew up loving the musical Annie and the 2014 remake of the original has established itself in my book as a classic. I truly believe that this new generation will fall in love with this film, it's cast and it's amazing bonafide songs. Jamie fox's spin on the original daddy Warbuck's role really adds an element to Warbuck's character. The way he captures the emotion of love for Annie will leave you in tears. He really makes you believe every emotion he plays. The whole cast performance is excellent no boring roles. Cameron Diaz scores as Miss Hannigan and Mr. Warbucks poll drivers add an edge of excitement the whole way through. The black girl that plays Annie is beautiful and is an amazing actress not to mention has a voice that is captivating! This movie had me shout at the end in the theater "This is the best movie ever!" and I really do mean that it doesn't matter what color Annie is the storyline is universal and crosses all color lines!. I love the old Annie and it will always be a fave of mine but I LOVE the new one even more! Way to Go Pinkett and Carter Family!!!! You hit a home run with this one!:) Children of all colors can now see themselves in roles such as this and I think that's awesome!!.

This was a great family film. It was very refreshing and it was lovely and warm. The bad reviews beg me to question if the reviewers watched the film determined not to like so that they could right a miserable review. I thoroughly enjoyed it and I think every child would enjoy it also. Definitely worth taking your children (who are probably more open-minded and socially intelligent) to go and see it!
I took my two grandchildren to see Annie yesterday and thought it was

I'm convinced that Annie is a movie entirely composed of cutsey rich-kid filler activities, with a misunderstanding thrown in at the very end trying to masquerade as conflict. Children might enjoy it as mindless fun, but don't be surprised if your kids' IQ suddenly drop by a few dozen points.

I liked a lot the movie,my family liked it ,too.I haven't seen the original movie but I think this work is fresh and brand new,containing new things that the current globalized world offers us and the original didn't.Hey,what about "Asyulus" 's review,calm down buddy you don't need to show your disgrace to an actor just for not following the original movie actor's look,it sounds like you are discriminating,more respect please!!!!

First off, before the review, let me just say, most of these reviews are comparing the 2014 edition of Annie to  the previous two renditions and the musical. They wanted to make an age-old story available to today's youth, without their parents having to give their kids a history lesson in the process. Now, the review. The movie and soundtrack were amazing, with such pretty voices. The storyline was great and modern, adjusted to today's youth. I give it a ten overall.

Loved it. I've seen the original and loved that. This is an updated version and it was well done. Yes it was updated... meaning to modern day, instead of the great depression. So the music, the values, the toys, the attitudes should all change. If you are looking for the original, watch the original (which was also amazing). But this one has a beautiful new touch for a new generation of families.  As a professional musician, I appreciate the arrangements of the the classic songs. They were not overdone, but the sounds and transitions were updated to sound modern. The new Annie is even cuter than the first and Jamie does an outstanding job playing cold and jaded businessman. The storyline is excellent by itself and would deserve at least a 3 stars without anything else but I do believe it was not only done well but took you on an emotional journey. I cannot believe that people are giving this movie low ratings.  And to say that Wallis wasn't good?... or sickeningly cute... that sounds crazy or simply like a "hater".  I hate saying this, but it makes me ask the question, is it just because this is a black Annie? Truly, to not like this movie I question how much of a heart one could have. I would say its un-american to not like a movie that so portrays the pursuit of happiness that resounds through our American spirit.

This movie was put together nicely so that even young children could watch without becoming depressed, unlike the original. It had a very upbeat feel to it. (Please use spell check. It's free and readily available.)

When I first watched the trailer for this movie, I was actually really excited for a fresh take on a musical that was sort of becoming stale for me. Then the clips of the songs started to be released and I was extremely disappointed in the overproduced pop sound of all of the music. With all of the autotune, Rose Byrne sounded more like the robotic smart house singing rather a human being.

The first movie version was a decent translation of the original stage musical. This new variation is so reworked by Hollywood hacks that it bears little resemblance to the original (it's even been moved to present day NYC). The handful of songs that remain are supplemented with some new updated ones and they're all overproduced and flat. Quvenzhané Wallis in the title role is cute. The other leads (Jamie Foxx and Cameron Diaz) are woefully unfunny and the staging is uninventive. Overall, the film has energy but no heart or charm. For a cast that features black actors in the leads, this is sadly soulless.

A remake of the classic musical isn't a terrible idea, but this version misses the mark by a long way. Wallis is very good as the young orphan, and Rose Byrne does the best she can with very little, but Foxx is woefully miscast and Diaz appears to be trying to win an award for worst overacting of the year. The songs still hold up but they needed a better film to carry them than this

It was fine.  I liked the humor and story, the singing was a little much at times, but it was still a solidly good comedy.  I have however never seen the original, or any stage version and that seems to be what most people complaining about are comparing it to past versions they already saw.  If you have never seen any version of Annie, you might just enjoy it.  (It was way better than what I read from critics etc.)
I was ready to be mad at the metascore here but then I saw that people rated the original a 39. Don't go to movies for children, if you don't like childrens movies.

Quvenzhane Wallis shines, but that can't help "Annie" from feeling like the result of what would happen if you took the plot from "The Game Plan" and made it into a musical where everyone sounds like T-Pain. Cameron Diaz is just unbearable; she needs to retire.

I was such a fan of Annie since I was a little girl, so I was really looking forward to watching this latest Annie movie. I loved the singing and dancing. It brings back a lot of great memories of my childhood.

My family loved this.  It occasionally misses the mark but it is entertaining throughout, with a lot of energy in the well put together musical scenes, a mostly great cast with particular note for Quvenzhane Wallis, Jamie Foxx, Rose Byrne and Adewale Akkinuoye-Agbaje and an altogether feel good effect. I expected to hate it and found myself watching the whole thing and caring about the plot and I haven't minded my seven year-old daughter watching it three times over in two days.

Too much pedo vibe for me Jamie Foxx. Casting of this movie was way off no one fit their roles. Also did anyone receive music or vocal training  I know Foxx cant sing but really there has to be the current cast of any production of Annie around to do this. Or it could be these types of stories cant be done in modern times without being creepy.

Despite how bad Will Gluck's script of Annie (the remake), this film has good music. And talent actors (expect Cameron Diaz). This is kind of a heart warming film, in this musical there are a ton of lip sinking, so i am confused if there singing or not? the film is kind of embarrassing just a little. Jamie Fox as the mayor is really selfish at first so he is unlike able, Rose Byrne is enjoyable. Quvenzhané Wallis is a sweet little girl with a sparkling voice, that makes this movie slightly better. Her acting is okay. Grade B-

This is the result when you have too many good ideas and put them all together, it doesn't work at all. I watched it with my family and we were bored of everyone singing every 5 min. At the last minute I tought the dog was going to sing to be honest. The presence of stars like Cameron Diaz, Rihanna and Sia (with awkward cameos) brings some points to watch this film. But when you make a movie you need to show that, a movie, not a musical even thought it was based on the original musical, the central theme of the story disappears when you are watching it and being interrupted by a random moment when a starring role is singing. I admit that the soundtrack is good and renovated, but the soundtrack it's the soundtrack, you can't put the whole thing in a movie and lose the story that way. In the other hand the visuals and the acting was very good with so much quality.

A too late review: The big way from Hollywood of put classic characters in remakes or reboots happening on present day don't works. They forget that essence of those movies was at that time and should be kept with the original characters. But the songs with modern twist were the great triumph.
Another remake of a movie that was already alright back in the 80's and 90's, and you can already guess that this movie isn't all that good.

This is honestly one of the best movies I've seen everyone whose giving this a below 5 are literally comparing it to the previous versions, I really enjoyed this version because it appeals to almost all audience (except those guys who can't be happy with anything *cough the guys who gave this a below 5 cough* I highly recommend this movie.
Great family friendly movie with a warm plot and great acting. Jammie Foxx is a pro in the business

I took my 7-year-old daughter to see this movie and we both LOVED it (especially the music). The songs were so catchy that I ended up buying the soundtrack so that we could keep enjoying it. I purchased the movie from the Google play store too. I am a huge fan of the original Annie and now this remake has a special place in my heart also. The casting was very well done. The best thing about this movie IMO is the songs. The plot is still the same classic tale as told in the original Annie.
I truly enjoyed this movie and found it creative and entertaining. A movie worth watching.

Well, how about that. They went and made another Annie movie. Honestly, I'm not surprised: I mean, EVERYBODY wanted to see this happen, right? Children shred tears, there were riots in the streets and entire wars erupted, all because there was not a remake of that musical about the bland red-haired girl you kind of remember a tiny bit. Well, thanks to the lovely, amazing people at Sony Pictures, the world is at peace once more. Thank you ever so much, Sony. Where would we be as a society without you?

A good try to tranlate this movie back onto the sliver screen. While the movie is not quite the train wreck most are making it out to be it is not perfect either. The girl who plays annie actually does a decent job and is prably the best part of this movie. I appreciate them trying to make a slightly a new idea of the beloved musical. However It's medicorly executed. They could have done without the auto tune but I see there trying to market toward younger people who might not be familiar with annie. Cameron diez did a horrible job as ms.hannigan. Some of the songs are good like I don't need anything but you and easy street. Overall this is just an ok adaptation of the beloved musical however if you want a good musical movie go see les miserables Chicago or into the woods

I really enjoyed the original Annie but this wasn't the worst adaptation. a lot more urban and new songs a log with the classics. I liked the cast and the story though I feel they didn't make it as harsh as it was in the original. I think the main issue I had was the lip syncing it looked so obvious most of the time. Not bad though.
